title: DAISIE Contributing Guidelines
text: Cover new functions unit test. Unit tests function way ensure new functions behave expected, internal form documentation. Unit tests cover things : correct type returned function called correctly, boundary cases behave expected, simple, short runs function return expected, correct output. helper function unit testing available usethis::use_test(). cursor function requiring testing, new file skeleton code testing generated. Test coverage can calculated using function devtools::test_coverage(). produce window function’s coverage across whole package. new functions must (least) 100% coverage. Integration tests encouraged. Integration tests, unlike unit tests, test functionality package unified way. Examples integration testing include testing entire ML routine. integration tests generally much slower run, request skipped local builds run Travis CI. Care still taken balance test’s speed usefulness, try make fast possible. still impossible, final option include said integration test DAISIE’s sister package DAISIEtesting, built specifically purpose.

title: DAISIE Contributing Guidelines

Use devtools::document() write NAMESPACE. functions documented using shortcut Ctrl + Alt + Shift + R cursor function name. write skeleton function documentation can write function description parameters, etc. Every function needs documentation. includes helper secondary functions. Internal functions require explicit documentation entry CRAN manual, marked @keyword Internal ensure developer documentation still accessible, preventing unnecessary clutter user manual. Authorship/blame. direct indirect contributor piece code listed @author, unless specifically requested author. Similarly, code refers specific publication, please include formatted citation @references. title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: want start directly model fitting can skip step go step 2. Load phylogenetic data Eleutherodacylus frogs island Hispaniola (used Etienne et al. 2020). dataset contains times colonization branching times species Eleutherodactylus frogs found island. data extracted dated molecular phylogeny Dugo-Cota et al 2019 (Ecology Letters 22:884–893). dataset includes 65 extant species, result five independent colonisation events island Hispaniola. can load data table/tibble format, making sure table headers match ones example. Eleutherodactylus data table
code: data(frogs_datatable, package = "DAISIE")

previous_headings: 1. Load, prepare and visualize data
what: The table contains the following 4 columns (column headers need to be written exactly like this):
title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: Clade_name - Name clade/lineage island (e.g. clade code, genus name) Status - Endemicity status clade. Can following Endemic; Non_endemic; Endemic_MaxAge, Non_Endemic_MaxAge latter two options cases time colonisation believed overestimate. cases, DAISIE assume colonisation happened time colonisation time given Branching_times present, colonisation time given Branching_times age first cladogenesis event lineage (). MaxAge options can also used colonization time unknown, specifying “NA” column Branching_times, case DAISIE assume colonisation happened time age island present. Missing_species - Number extant species belong clade included phylogeny. Branching_times - First element colonisation time, subsequent elements branching times within island . e.g. c(colonisation_time, branching_time1; branching_time2). colonisation time unknown, ‘NA’ can specified. branching times unknown, replace ‘NA’ - just add corresponding number missing species column Missing_species.

what: 1.1. Create DAISIE datalist from the input table
title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: case assuming island age 30 million years Hispaniola mainland pool size 300 species (number species may colonize island).
code: frogs_datalist <- DAISIE_dataprep(         datatable = frogs_datatable,         island_age = 30,         M = 300)

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: Just type: DAISIE datalist includes data table frogs format DAISIE object can read subsequent maximum likelihood functions (e.g DAISIE_ML, DAISIE_ML_IW ). includes age island, number mainland species currently present island list extant independent colonisation events, including colonization branching times.
code: frogs_datalist

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: plot shows different colonization events, times colonization branching times (horizontal ticks). Dashed line shows age island. n=number species; m= number species missing.
code: DAISIE_plot_island(frogs_datalist)

previous_headings: 1.3. Visualise the data
title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
code: # DAISIE_plot_age_diversity(frogs_datalist)

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: skipped step 1, first load Hispaniola Eleutherodactylus datalist. _ fit five different DAISIE models phylogenetic data contained frogs_datalist: DI - diversity-independent model. Model K’ (carrying-capacity) set Inf. CS - clade-specific diversity-dependence model. CS_no_ana - clade-specific diversity-dependence model anagenesis. Equivalent CS model Etienne et al. 2020. IW - island-wide diversity-dependence model. IW_no_ana - island-wide diversity-dependence model anagenesis. Equivalent IW model Etienne et al. 2020. use DAISIE_ML DAISIE_ML_IW functions optimise likelihood. important settings specify functions: datalist - name DAISIE datalist (case frogs_datalist) Rate cladogenesis (per species island per time unit) Rate extinction (per species island per time unit) Carrying-capacity (K’) - maximum number species clade can reach island CS models; maximum number species island across clades IW models. Rate colonisation (per species mainland per time unit) Rate anagenesis (per species island per time unit) idparsopt - position parameters optimise (e.g. optimize cladogenesis anagenesis c(1,5). parsfix - parameters fixed, specify value (e.g. fixing K’ Inf fixing anagenesis 0 - c(Inf,0). idparsfix - position paratemers fixed (e.g. fix K’ anagenesis c(3,5)). ddmodel - Set 0 diversity-independent models; 11 diversity-dependent models (IW CS) cladogenesis colonisation decline linearly diversity. options. many options, check ? DAISIE_ML   IW models (IW IW_no_ana) use island-wide version DAISIE, computationally demanding. require high memory long run times. recommend run cluster. CS models can run regular computer laptop.
code: data(frogs_datalist)

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: model contains 4 parameters: 1 - cladogenesis 2 - extinction 4 - colonisation 5 - anagenesis K’ fixed Inf Set ddmodel=0
code: DAISIE_ML(   datalist = frogs_datalist,   initparsopt = c(0.18,0.03,0.0006,2),   idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5),   ddmodel = 0,   parsfix = Inf,   idparsfix = 3 ) #>    lambda_c         mu   K        gamma lambda_a    loglik df conv #> 1 0.1789218 0.02509053 Inf 0.0006259365  1568.88 -209.8634  4    0

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: model contains 5 parameters: 1 - cladogenesis 2 - extinction 3 - K’ 4 - colonisation 5 - anagenesis Set ddmodel=11 Output shown .
code: DAISIE_ML(   datalist = frogs_datalist,   initparsopt = c(0.44,0.11,36.44,0.0007,2),   idparsopt = c(1,2,3,4,5),   ddmodel = 11,   parsfix = NULL,   idparsfix = NULL )

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: model contains 4 parameters: 1 - cladogenesis 2 - extinction 3 - K’ 4 - colonisation Set ddmodel=11 Output shown .
code: DAISIE_ML(   datalist = frogs_datalist,   initparsopt = c(0.44,0.11,36.44,0.0007),   idparsopt = c(1,2,3,4),   ddmodel = 11,   parsfix = 0,   idparsfix = 5 )

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: model contains 5 parameters: 1 - cladogenesis 2 - extinction 3 - K’ 4 - colonisation 5 - anagenesis Set ddmodel=11 Output shown (recommended run cluster).
code: DAISIE_ML_IW(   datalist = frogs_datalist,   initparsopt = c(0.41, 0.17, 131.7, 0.0012, 2),   idparsopt = c(1,2,3,4,5),   ddmodel = 11,   parsfix = NULL,   idparsfix = NULL )

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: model contains 4 parameters: 1 - cladogenesis 2 - extinction 3 - K’ 4 - colonisation Set ddmodel=11 Output shown (recommended run cluster).
code: DAISIE_ML_IW(   datalist = frogs_datalist,   initparsopt = c(0.40, 0.17, 131.83, 0.0012),   idparsopt = c(1,2,3,4),   ddmodel = 11,   parsfix = 0,   idparsfix = 5 )

title: Demo: Fitting clade-specific and island-wide diversity-dependence models in DAISIE
text: use DAISIE_sim function, simulates diversity dynamics island island birth specificied island age, based given set parameters (cladogenesis, extinction, carrying-capacity (K’), colonisation, anagenesis). important settings specify DAISIE_sim function: Rate cladogenesis Rate extinction Carrying-capacity (K’) Rate colonisation Rate anagenesis replicates - Number replicates simulate time - Time run simulation, example 20 million years M - Number species mainland pool divdepmodel - set CS clade-specific diversity-dependence; IW island-wide diversity-dependence Simulate CS model 30 million years, 100 replicates: Simulate IW model 30 million years, 100 replicates:

what: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction
title: Demo optimizing parameters
text: Citation: Valente LM, Phillimore AB, Etienne RS (2015) Equilibrium non- equilibrium dynamics simultaneously operate Galápagos islands. Ecology Letters, press.

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction
title: Demo optimizing parameters
text: load package: raw dataset inputted table. Galápagos dataset table can visualized : row table represents independent colonisation event. table four columns: Clade_name: name independent colonization event. Endemic: applicable anagenetic species radiations. Non_endemic: taxon endemic island, age colonisation based phylogeny island non-island populations species sampled. Non_endemic_MaxAge: taxon endemic island, upper bound time colonisation island known. applies individuals island population species sampled, age species known. Endemic&Non_Endemic: endemic clade present mainland ancestor re-colonized. remote islands expected rare. Missing_species: Number island species sampled particular clade (applicable radiations). Branching_times – stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge Endemic anagenetic species. cladogenetic species branching times radiation including stem age radiation. Note – species within radiation found island (e.g. back-colonisation) branching times species excluded, mainland species pool treated static. data can also visualized:
code: library(DAISIE) data(Galapagos_datatable) knitr::kable(Galapagos_datatable) DAISIE::DAISIE_plot_island(Galapagos_datatable, island_age = 4) #> Colonisation time of 7.456 for Coccyzus is older than island age #> Colonisation time of 10.285 for Pyrocephalus is older than island age

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction
what: Formatting table to run in DAISIE
title: Demo optimizing parameters
text: running analyses, datatable needs converted DAISIE datalist format using function DAISIE_dataprep. prepare two different datalists based Galápagos datatable. 1st datalist treat taxa equivalent. specify island age four million years (island_age=4) mainland pool size 1000 (M=1000). 2nd datalist allow Darwin’s finches form separate group rates can decoupled governing macroevolutionary process clades (number_clade_types=2 list_type2_clades = “Finches”). set proportion Darwin’s finch type species mainland pool 0.163. (prop_type2_pool=0.163). prop_type2_pool specified default given value proportion Galapagos lineages Darwin’s finches represent (1/8=0.125 case). objects Galapagos_datalist Galapagos_datalist_2types can now run directly DAISIE functions.
code: data(Galapagos_datatable)         Galapagos_datalist <- DAISIE_dataprep(    datatable = Galapagos_datatable,    island_age = 4,    M = 1000 ) #> Colonisation time of 7.456 for Coccyzus is older than island age #> Colonisation time of 10.285 for Pyrocephalus is older than island age data(Galapagos_datatable)   Galapagos_datalist_2types <- DAISIE_dataprep(    datatable = Galapagos_datatable,    island_age = 4,    M = 1000,    number_clade_types = 2,    list_type2_clades = "Finches",    prop_type2_pool = 0.163 ) #> Colonisation time of 7.456 for Coccyzus is older than island age #> Colonisation time of 10.285 for Pyrocephalus is older than island age

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction
title: Demo optimizing parameters
text: function conducts maximum likelihood optimization DAISIE model parameters called DAISIE_ML. Different models can specified using ddmodel option DAISIE_ML: ddmodel = 0 : diversity-dependence ddmodel = 1 : linear diversity-dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 11: linear diversity-dependence speciation immigration rate ddmodel = 2 : exponential diversity-dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential diversity-dependence speciation immigration rate Different types parameters can optimized fixed. parameters given following order: (1) cladogenesis rate, (2) extinction rate, (3) K’ carrying capacity (maximum number species clade can attain within island), (4) colonisation rate, (5) anagenesis rate. identities parameters optimized fixed specified idparsopt idparsfix within DAISIE_ML function. example, optimize parameters set idparsopt=1:5 idparsfix=NULL. optimize parameters fix rate extinction, set idparsopt=c(1,3,4,5) idparsfix=2. optimize parameters except cladogenesis anagenesis set idparsopt=c(2,3,4) idparsfix=c(1,5). values parameters used initial values optimization specified initparsopt, values fixed specified parsfix. example, want optimize parameters starting value 2 set initparsopt=c(2,2,2,2,2) parsfix=NULL. want starting rates 0.1, K’ fixed 20, use initparsopt=c(0.1,0.1,0.1,0.1) parsfix=20. running data, strongly recommend test multiple initial starting parameters model, particularly optimizing models multiple free parameters, high risk trapped local likelihood sub-optima. also suggest running two rounds optimization using optimized parameter set 1st round initial starting values 2nd round. Also note initial starting values examples tutorial may appropriate data.

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction > Optimizing parameters using maximum likelihood
what: Example 1: Optimizing all parameters, with diversity-dependence in speciation and colonisation
title: Demo optimizing parameters
text: now optimize five parameters datalist clades share parameters. set model linear diversity-dependence speciation rate immigration rate using ddmodel=11. set initial rate cladogenesis 2.5, initial rate extinction 2.7, initial K’ value 20, initial rate colonisation 0.009 initial rate anagenesis 1.01 (initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01)). optimize 5 parameters (idparsopt = 1:5) fix parameters (parsfix = NULL, idparsfix = NULL). take several minutes run. parameters optimized fixed well loglikelihood initial starting parameters set shown top screen output DAISIE_ML. optimization completed, program output maximum likelihood parameter estimates maximum loglikelihood value. given dataset, likelihood different DAISIE models can compared information criteria BIC AIC.
code: data(Galapagos_datalist)   DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist,    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01),    ddmodel = 11,    idparsopt = 1:5,    parsfix = NULL,    idparsfix = NULL )

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction > Optimizing parameters using maximum likelihood
what: Example 4: Optimizing all parameters, but allowing Darwin’s finches to have a separate rate of cladogenesis.
title: Demo optimizing parameters
text: example use datalist Darwin’s finches specified separate type: Galapagos_datalist_2types. two types species considered, parameters second type species order first set parameters, start number 6: (6) cladogenesis rate type 2 species, (7) extinction rate type 2 species, (8) K’ type 2 species, (9) colonisation rate type 2 species, (10) anagenesis rate type 2 species. also additional parameter 2 types species considered: proportion species type 2 mainland pool. parameter number 11. optimize parameters, allow finches separate rate cladogenesis. fix proportion type 2 species mainland pool 0.163 (therefore fixing parameter 11 idparsfix=11 parsfix=0.163). Note allowing rate cladogenesis Darwin’s finches vary background rate, need specify rates Darwin’s finches remain background – using idparsnoshift = c(7,8,9,10)).
code: data(Galapagos_datalist_2types)   DAISIE_ML(    ddmodel=11,    datalist=Galapagos_datalist_2types,    initparsopt= c(0.38,0.55,20,0.004,1.1,2.28),    idparsopt = c(1,2,3,4,5,6),    parsfix = 0.163,    idparsfix = c(11),    idparsnoshift = c(7,8,9,10) )

text: load package:
code: library(DAISIE)

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction
title: Demo simulating islands
text: function DAISIE_sim allows simulation DAISIE models plots results. user specifies parameters simulated, number replicates, length simulation (typically island age), number species mainland pool. plot_sims option set default (TRUE) function produce species- -time plot showing accumulation total, endemic non-endemic species time, well confidence intervals total number species. shorten run-time vignette, reduce number n_replicates. increased accuracy, increase number.
code: n_mainland_species <- 1000 island_age <- 4 n_replicates <- 10

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction > Simulating islands
what: Example 5.1 – Simulating 10 islands with no diversity-dependence, all species sharing the same parameters, and plotting the results
title: Demo simulating islands
text: object island_replicates contains results simulation DAISIE format. 10 islands stored object, island replicate can viewed separately. example, type island_replicates[[1]] view first replicate. element list relating island contains table number species time, well branching time information independent colonisation event extant end simulation.
code: set.seed(42) clado_rate <- 2.550687345 # cladogenesis rate ext_rate <- 2.683454548 # extinction rate clade_carr_cap <- Inf # clade-level carrying capacity imm_rate <- 0.00933207 # immigration rate ana_rate <- 1.010073119 # anagenesis rate  island_replicates <- DAISIE_sim_cr(    time = island_age,   M = n_mainland_species,    pars = c(clado_rate, ext_rate, clade_carr_cap, imm_rate, ana_rate),   replicates = n_replicates,   plot_sims = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE ) DAISIE_plot_sims(island_replicates = island_replicates)

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction > Simulating islands
what: Example 5.2 – Simulating 10 islands with diversity-dependence (K’=10), all species sharing the same parameters, and plotting the results
title: Demo simulating islands
code: clado_rate <- 2.550687345 # cladogenesis rate ext_rate <- 2.683454548 # extinction rate clade_carr_cap <- 10.0  # clade-level carrying capacity imm_rate <- 0.00933207 # immigration rate ana_rate <- 1.010073119 # anagenesis rate  island_replicates_K <- DAISIE_sim_cr(    time = island_age,    M = n_mainland_species,    pars = c(clado_rate, ext_rate, clade_carr_cap, imm_rate, ana_rate),   replicates = n_replicates,   plot_sims = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )  DAISIE_plot_sims(island_replicates_K)

previous_headings: DAISIE – Dynamic Assembly of Island biotas through Speciation, Immigration and Extinction > Simulating islands
what: Example 5.3 – Simulating 10 islands allowing Darwin’s finches to have a higher rate of cladogenesis:
title: Demo simulating islands
text: produces figure similar Fig. 2, three plots: one total number species, one species type 1 one species type 2. Accessing island replicate individually (e.g. island_replicates_2types[[15]]) shows information branching times species--time tables total, type 1 species type 2 species.
code: clado_rate_1 <- 0.38 # cladogenesis rate ext_rate_1 <- 0.55 # extinction rate clade_carr_cap_1 <- Inf  # clade-level carrying capacity imm_rate_1 <- 0.04 # immigration rate ana_rate_1 <- 1.10 # anagenesis rate  clado_rate_2 <- 0.38 # cladogenesis rate ext_rate_2 <- ext_rate_1 # extinction rate clade_carr_cap_2 <- clade_carr_cap_1  # clade-level carrying capacity imm_rate_2 <- imm_rate_1 # immigration rate ana_rate_2 <- ana_rate_1 # anagenesis rate  island_replicates_2types <- DAISIE_sim_cr(    time = island_age,   M = n_mainland_species,    pars = c(     clado_rate_1, ext_rate_1, clade_carr_cap_1, imm_rate_1, ana_rate_1,     clado_rate_2, ext_rate_2, clade_carr_cap_2, imm_rate_2, ana_rate_2   ),   replicates = n_replicates,    prop_type2_pool = 0.163,   plot_sims = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE ) DAISIE_plot_sims(island_replicates_2types)

what: Colonization and branching times of Noctilionoid bats from the Greater Antilles. — Bats_GreaterAntilles
title: Colonization and branching times of Noctilionoid bats from the Greater Antilles. — Bats_GreaterAntilles
text: list containing colonization branching times noctilionoid bats Greater Antilles. Main dataset used Valente, Etienne Dávalos (2017) Nature Ecology Evolution. Island age 20 Myr mainland pool size 100 species. first element list two components: $island_age - island age $not_present - number mainland lineages present island  following elements list contain information single colonist lineage island 5 components:$colonist_name - name species clade colonized island $branching_times - island age followed stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge species Endemic species close relatives island. endemic clades one species island (cladogenetic clades/ radiations) island age followed branching times island clade including stem age clade.$stac - status colonist  * Non_endemic_MaxAge: 1  * Endemic: 2  * Endemic&Non_Endemic: 3  * Non_endemic: 4  * Endemic_MaxAge: 5 6 $missing_species - number island species sampled particular clade (applicable endemic clades) $type1or2 - whether colonist belongs type 1 type 2. dataset equal 1.

title: Colonization and branching times of Noctilionoid bats from the Greater Antilles. — Bats_GreaterAntilles

what: The expected number of endemics and non-endemics under the DAISIE model — DAISIE_ExpEIN
title: The expected number of endemics and non-endemics under the DAISIE model — DAISIE_ExpEIN
text: function calculates expected number endemics, non-endemics sum given set parameter values, given mainland species pool size given time

title: The expected number of endemics and non-endemics under the DAISIE model — DAISIE_ExpEIN
code: DAISIE_ExpEIN(t, pars, M, initEI = c(0, 0))

title: The expected number of endemics and non-endemics under the DAISIE model — DAISIE_ExpEIN
text: t time expectations need computed. pars numeric vector containing model parameters: pars[1]: lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) pars[2]: mu (extinction rate) pars[3]: K (carrying capacity), set K=Inf diversity   independence. pars[4]: gamma (immigration rate) pars[5]: lambda^(anagenesis rate) pars[6]: lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) either type 2 species   rate set 2 rate shift model pars[7]: mu (extinction rate) either type 2 species rate   set 2 rate shift model pars[8]: K (carrying capacity) either type 2 species rate   set 2 rate shift model, set K=Inf diversity independence. pars[9]: gamma (immigration rate) either type 2 species   rate set 2 rate shift model pars[10]: lambda^(anagenesis rate) either type 2   species rate set 2 rate shift model Elements 6:10 required type 2 species included rate shift model. DAISIE_sim_relaxed_rate() pars[6] standard deviation gamma distribution relaxed parameter parameter chosen relaxed_par argument mean gamma distribution relaxed parameter. M Numeric defining size mainland pool, .e. number species can potentially colonize island. initEI initial values number endemics   non-endemics. DAISIE_probdist() DAISIE_margprobdist() either initprobs must NULL. DAISIE_numcol() NULL, assumed island   empty.

title: The expected number of endemics and non-endemics under the DAISIE model — DAISIE_ExpEIN
text: output list three elements: ExpE number endemic species ExpI number non-endemic species ExpN sum number endemics non-endemics

text: datalist Data object containing information colonisation branching times. object can generated using DAISIE_dataprep function, converts user-specified data table data object, object can course also entered directly. R list object following elements. first element list two three components: $island_age - island age  , depending whether distinction types made, :$not_present - number mainland lineages present island  :$not_present_type1 - number mainland lineages type 1 present island $not_present_type2 - number mainland lineages type 2 present island  remaining elements list contains information single colonist lineage island 5 components:$colonist_name - name species clade colonized island $branching_times - island age followed stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge species Endemic species close relatives island. endemic clades one species island (cladogenetic clades/ radiations) island age followed branching times island clade including stem age clade$stac - status colonist  * Non_endemic_MaxAge: 1  * Endemic: 2  * Endemic&Non_Endemic: 3  * Non_Endemic: 4  * Endemic_Singleton_MaxAge: 5  * Endemic_Clade_MaxAge: 6  * Endemic&Non_Endemic_Clade_MaxAge: 7 $missing_species - number island species sampled particular clade (applicable endemic clades) $type1or2 - whether colonist belongs type 1 type 2 initparsopt initial values parameters must optimized, positive. idparsopt ids parameters must optimized. ids defined follows:  id = 1 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate)  id = 2 corresponds mu (extinction rate)  id = 3 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity)  id = 4 corresponds gamma (immigration rate)  id = 5 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate)  id = 6 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) optional subset species  id = 7 corresponds mu (extinction rate) optional subset species id = 8 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity) optional subset species id = 9 corresponds gamma (immigration rate) optional subset species id = 10 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate) optional subset species id = 11 corresponds p_f (fraction mainland species belongs second subset species. parsfix values parameters optimized. idparsfix ids parameters optimized, e.g. c(1,3) lambda^c K optimized. endmc Numeric many simulations run. res Sets maximum number species probability must computed, must larger size largest clade. cond cond = 0 : conditioning island age  cond = 1 : conditioning island age non-extinction island biota . cond > 1 : conditioning island age least cond colonizations island. last option yet available IW model ddmodel Sets model diversity-dependence:  ddmodel = 0 : diversity dependence  ddmodel = 1 : linear dependence speciation rate  ddmodel = 11: linear dependence speciation rate immigration rate  ddmodel = 2 : exponential dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential dependence speciation rate immigration rate

title: IW concurrency control — DAISIE_IW_num_threads
text: Sets retrieves number threads used odeint solver.

title: IW concurrency control — DAISIE_IW_num_threads
code: DAISIE_IW_num_threads(num_threads)

title: IW concurrency control — DAISIE_IW_num_threads
text: num_threads num_threads < 0 omitted: retrieves number threads. num_threads = 0: sets number threads number available cores. num_threads = 1: single-threaded execution. num_threads > 1: sets number threads num_threads.

title: IW concurrency control — DAISIE_IW_num_threads
text: number threads

title: IW concurrency control — DAISIE_IW_num_threads
text: maximum number threads limited value C++ standard library function std::thread::hardware_concurrency(). also default number threads upon library load. Multithreading incurs overhead. Therefore, single-threaded execution might faster small systems.

what: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
text: function computes maximum likelihood estimates parameters DAISIE model clade-specific diversity-dependence data lineages colonizing island. also outputs corresponding loglikelihood can used model comparisons. result sort(c(idparsopt, idparsfix, idparsnoshift)) identical c(1:10). , error reported input incoherent. happens length initparsopt different length idparsopt, length parsfix different length idparsfix. Including 11th parameter (p_f) either idparsopt idparsfix (therefore initparsopt parsfix) optional. parameter specified, information data used, otherwise information data overruled.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
code: DAISIE_ML_CS(   datalist,   datatype = "single",   initparsopt,   idparsopt,   parsfix,   idparsfix,   idparsnoshift = 6:10,   idparsmat = NULL,   res = 100,   ddmodel = 0,   cond = 0,   island_ontogeny = NA,   eqmodel = 0,   x_E = 0.95,   x_I = 0.98,   tol = c(1e-04, 1e-05, 1e-07),   maxiter = 1000 * round((1.25)^length(idparsopt)),   methode = "lsodes",   optimmethod = "subplex",   CS_version = 1,   verbose = 0,   tolint = c(1e-16, 1e-10),   jitter = 0,   num_cycles = 1,   function_to_optimize = "DAISIE_exact" )

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
text: datalist Data object containing information colonisation branching times. object can generated using DAISIE_dataprep function, converts user-specified data table data object, object can course also entered directly. R list object following elements. first element list two three components: $island_age - island age  , depending whether distinction types made, :$not_present - number mainland lineages present island  :$not_present_type1 - number mainland lineages type 1 present island $not_present_type2 - number mainland lineages type 2 present island  remaining elements list contains information single colonist lineage island 5 components:$colonist_name - name species clade colonized island $branching_times - island age followed stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge species Endemic species close relatives island. endemic clades one species island (cladogenetic clades/ radiations) island age followed branching times island clade including stem age clade$stac - status colonist  * Non_endemic_MaxAge: 1  * Endemic: 2  * Endemic&Non_Endemic: 3  * Non_Endemic: 4  * Endemic_Singleton_MaxAge: 5  * Endemic_Clade_MaxAge: 6  * Endemic&Non_Endemic_Clade_MaxAge: 7 $missing_species - number island species sampled particular clade (applicable endemic clades) $type1or2 - whether colonist belongs type 1 type 2 datatype Sets type data: 'single' single island archipelago treated one, 'multiple' multiple archipelagoes potentially sharing parameters. initparsopt initial values parameters must optimized, positive. idparsopt ids parameters must optimized. ids defined follows:  id = 1 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate)  id = 2 corresponds mu (extinction rate)  id = 3 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity)  id = 4 corresponds gamma (immigration rate)  id = 5 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate)  id = 6 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) optional subset species  id = 7 corresponds mu (extinction rate) optional subset species id = 8 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity) optional subset species id = 9 corresponds gamma (immigration rate) optional subset species id = 10 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate) optional subset species id = 11 corresponds p_f (fraction mainland species belongs second subset species. parsfix values parameters optimized. idparsfix ids parameters optimized, e.g. c(1,3) lambda^c K optimized. idparsnoshift datatype = 'single' : ids parameters different two groups species; can apply ids 6:10, e.g. idparsnoshift = c(6,7) means lambda^c mu values groups. idparsmat datatype = 'multiple' : Matrix containing ids parameters, linking initparsopt parsfix. Per island system use following order:  * lac = (initial) cladogenesis rate  * mu = extinction rate  * K = maximum number species possible clade  * gam = (initial) immigration rate  * laa = (initial) anagenesis rate  Example: idparsmat = rbind(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), c(1, 2, 3, 6, 7)) different rates immigration anagenesis two islands. res Sets maximum number species probability must computed, must larger size largest clade. ddmodel Sets model diversity-dependence:  ddmodel = 0 : diversity dependence  ddmodel = 1 : linear dependence speciation rate  ddmodel = 11: linear dependence speciation rate immigration rate  ddmodel = 2 : exponential dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential dependence speciation rate immigration rate cond cond = 0 : conditioning island age  cond = 1 : conditioning island age non-extinction island biota . cond > 1 : conditioning island age least cond colonizations island. last option yet available IW model island_ontogeny DAISIE_sim_time_dep(), DAISIE_ML_CS plotting string describing type island ontogeny. Can "const", "beta" beta function describing area time.  functions numeric describing type island ontogeny. Can 0 constant, 1 beta function describing area time. ML functions island_ontogeny = NA assumes constant ontogeny. Time dependent estimation yet available development still ongoing. return error called case. eqmodel Sets equilibrium constraint can used likelihood optimization. available datatype = 'single'. eqmodel = 0 : equilibrium assumed  eqmodel = 13 : near-equilibrium assumed endemics using deterministic equation endemics immigrants. Endemics must within x_E equilibrium value eqmodel = 15 : near-equilibrium assumed endemics immigrants using deterministic equation endemics immigrants. Endemics must within x_E equilibrium value, non-endemics must within x_I equilibrium value. x_E Sets fraction equlibrium endemic diversity endemics assumed equilibrium; active eqmodel = 13 15. x_I Sets fraction equlibrium non-endemic diversity system assumed equilibrium; active eqmodel = 15. tol Sets tolerances optimization. Consists :  reltolx = relative tolerance parameter values optimization  reltolf = relative tolerance function value optimization  abstolx = absolute tolerance parameter values optimization. maxiter Sets maximum number iterations optimization. methode Method ODE-solver. Supported Boost ODEINT solvers (steppers) : "odeint::runge_kutta_cash_karp54" "odeint::runge_kutta_fehlberg78" "odeint::runge_kutta_dopri5" "odeint::bulirsch_stoer" without odeint::-prefix, ode method assumed. default method overall "lsodes" DAISIE_ML_CS() "ode45" ode() DAISIE_ML_IW(). optimmethod Method used likelihood optimization. Default `subplex` (see `subplex()` full details). Alternative "simplex" method previous versions. CS_version numeric list. Default 1 standard DAISIE model, relaxed-rate model list following elements: model: CS model run, options 1 single rate   DAISIE model, 2 multi-rate DAISIE, 0 IW test   model. relaxed_par: parameter relax (integrate ). Options "cladogenesis", "extinction", "carrying_capacity", "immigration", "anagenesis". verbose numeric vector length 1, simulations `DAISIEdataprep()` can `1` `0`, `1` gives intermediate output printed. ML functions numeric determining intermediate output printed. default: `0` print, `1` prints initial likelihood settings selected (parameters optimised, fixed shifted), `2` prints `1 also intermediate output parameters loglikelihood, `3` `2` prints intermediate progress likelihood computation. tolint Vector two elements containing absolute relative tolerance integration. jitter Numeric optimizer(). Jitters parameters optimized specified amount small, e.g. 1e-5. Jitter link{subplex}{subplex}() produces incorrect output due parameter transformation. num_cycles number cycles optimizer go . Default 1. function_to_optimize one can indicate use function ('DAISIE_approx') approximates DAISIE likelihood default value 'DAISIE_exact'). approximate likelihood can example used case exact one fails. still development.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
text: output dataframe containing estimated parameters maximum loglikelihood. lambda_c gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c, rate cladogenesis mu gives maximum likelihood estimate mu, extinction rate K gives maximum likelihood estimate K, carrying-capacity gamma gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma, immigration rate lambda_a gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^, rate anagenesis lambda_c2 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c2, rate cladogenesis optional second group species mu2 gives maximum likelihood estimate mu2, extinction rate optional second group species K2 gives maximum likelihood estimate K2, carrying-capacity optional second group species gamma2 gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma2, immigration rate optional second group species lambda_a2 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^a2, rate anagenesis optional second group species loglik gives maximum loglikelihood df gives number estimated parameters, .e. degrees feedom conv gives message convergence optimization; conv = 0 means convergence

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
text: Valente, L.M., .B. Phillimore R.S. Etienne (2015). Equilibrium non-equilibrium dynamics simultaneously operate Galapagos islands. Ecology Letters 18: 844-852. <doi:10.1111/ele.12461>.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
text: Rampal S. Etienne

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_ML
code: cat(" ### When all species have the same rates, and we want to optimize all 5 parameters, # we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist,    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01),    ddmodel = 11,    idparsopt = 1:5,    parsfix = NULL,    idparsfix = NULL )  ### When all species have the same rates, and we want to optimize all parameters # except K (which we set equal to Inf), we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist,    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,0.009,1.01),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5),    parsfix = Inf,    idparsfix = 3    )  ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different # rate of cladogenesis, and we want to optimize all parameters except K (which we # set equal to Inf), fixing the proportion of finch-type species at 0.163, we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types,    initparsopt = c(0.38,0.55,0.004,1.1,2.28),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,6),    parsfix = c(Inf,Inf,0.163),    idparsfix = c(3,8,11),    idparsnoshift = c(7,9,10)    )  ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different # rate of cladogenesis, extinction and a different K, and we want to optimize all # parameters, fixing the proportion of finch-type species at 0.163, we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types,    ddmodel = 11,    initparsopt = c(0.19,0.09,0.002,0.87,20,8.9,15),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,6,7,8),    parsfix = c(Inf,0.163),    idparsfix = c(3,11),    idparsnoshift = c(9,10)    )   ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different # rate of extinction, and we want to optimize all parameters except K (which we # set equal to Inf), and we also# want to estimate the fraction of finch species # in the mainland pool. we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types,    initparsopt = c(2.48,2.7,0.009,1.01,2.25,0.163),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,7,11),    parsfix = c(Inf,Inf),    idparsfix = c(3,8),    idparsnoshift = c(6,9,10)    )  ### When we have two islands with the same rates except for immigration and anagenesis rate, # and we want to optimize all parameters, we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = list(Galapagos_datalist,Galapagos_datalist),    datatype = 'multiple',    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01,0.009,1.01),    idparsmat = rbind(1:5,c(1:3,6,7)),    idparsopt = 1:7,    parsfix = NULL,    idparsfix = NULL )  ### When we consider the four Macaronesia archipelagoes and set all parameters the same # except for rates of cladogenesis, extinction and immigration for Canary Islands, # rate of cladogenesis is fixed to 0 for the other archipelagoes, # diversity-dependence is assumed to be absent # and we want to optimize all parameters, we use:  utils::data(Macaronesia_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Macaronesia_datalist,    datatype = 'multiple',    initparsopt = c(1.053151832,0.052148979,0.512939011,0.133766934,0.152763179),    idparsmat = rbind(1:5,c(6,2,3,7,5),1:5,1:5),    idparsopt = c(2,4,5,6,7),    parsfix = c(0,Inf),    idparsfix = c(1,3) )  ") #>  #> ### When all species have the same rates, and we want to optimize all 5 parameters, #> # we use: #>  #> utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = Galapagos_datalist, #>    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01), #>    ddmodel = 11, #>    idparsopt = 1:5, #>    parsfix = NULL, #>    idparsfix = NULL #> ) #>  #> ### When all species have the same rates, and we want to optimize all parameters #> # except K (which we set equal to Inf), we use: #>  #> utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = Galapagos_datalist, #>    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,0.009,1.01), #>    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5), #>    parsfix = Inf, #>    idparsfix = 3 #>    ) #>  #> ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different #> # rate of cladogenesis, and we want to optimize all parameters except K (which we #> # set equal to Inf), fixing the proportion of finch-type species at 0.163, we use: #>  #> utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types, #>    initparsopt = c(0.38,0.55,0.004,1.1,2.28), #>    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,6), #>    parsfix = c(Inf,Inf,0.163), #>    idparsfix = c(3,8,11), #>    idparsnoshift = c(7,9,10) #>    ) #>  #> ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different #> # rate of cladogenesis, extinction and a different K, and we want to optimize all #> # parameters, fixing the proportion of finch-type species at 0.163, we use: #>  #> utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types, #>    ddmodel = 11, #>    initparsopt = c(0.19,0.09,0.002,0.87,20,8.9,15), #>    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,6,7,8), #>    parsfix = c(Inf,0.163), #>    idparsfix = c(3,11), #>    idparsnoshift = c(9,10) #>    ) #>  #>  #> ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different #> # rate of extinction, and we want to optimize all parameters except K (which we #> # set equal to Inf), and we also# want to estimate the fraction of finch species #> # in the mainland pool. we use: #>  #> utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types, #>    initparsopt = c(2.48,2.7,0.009,1.01,2.25,0.163), #>    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,7,11), #>    parsfix = c(Inf,Inf), #>    idparsfix = c(3,8), #>    idparsnoshift = c(6,9,10) #>    ) #>  #> ### When we have two islands with the same rates except for immigration and anagenesis rate, #> # and we want to optimize all parameters, we use: #>  #> utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = list(Galapagos_datalist,Galapagos_datalist), #>    datatype = 'multiple', #>    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01,0.009,1.01), #>    idparsmat = rbind(1:5,c(1:3,6,7)), #>    idparsopt = 1:7, #>    parsfix = NULL, #>    idparsfix = NULL #> ) #>  #> ### When we consider the four Macaronesia archipelagoes and set all parameters the same #> # except for rates of cladogenesis, extinction and immigration for Canary Islands, #> # rate of cladogenesis is fixed to 0 for the other archipelagoes, #> # diversity-dependence is assumed to be absent #> # and we want to optimize all parameters, we use: #>  #> utils::data(Macaronesia_datalist) #> DAISIE_ML( #>    datalist = Macaronesia_datalist, #>    datatype = 'multiple', #>    initparsopt = c(1.053151832,0.052148979,0.512939011,0.133766934,0.152763179), #>    idparsmat = rbind(1:5,c(6,2,3,7,5),1:5,1:5), #>    idparsopt = c(2,4,5,6,7), #>    parsfix = c(0,Inf), #>    idparsfix = c(1,3) #> ) #>

text: datalist Data object containing information colonisation branching times. object can generated using DAISIE_dataprep function, converts user-specified data table data object, object can course also entered directly. R list object following elements. first element list two three components: $island_age - island age  , depending whether distinction types made, :$not_present - number mainland lineages present island  :$not_present_type1 - number mainland lineages type 1 present island $not_present_type2 - number mainland lineages type 2 present island  remaining elements list contains information single colonist lineage island 5 components:$colonist_name - name species clade colonized island $branching_times - island age followed stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge species Endemic species close relatives island. endemic clades one species island (cladogenetic clades/ radiations) island age followed branching times island clade including stem age clade$stac - status colonist  * Non_endemic_MaxAge: 1  * Endemic: 2  * Endemic&Non_Endemic: 3  * Non_Endemic: 4  * Endemic_Singleton_MaxAge: 5  * Endemic_Clade_MaxAge: 6  * Endemic&Non_Endemic_Clade_MaxAge: 7 $missing_species - number island species sampled particular clade (applicable endemic clades) $type1or2 - whether colonist belongs type 1 type 2 initparsopt initial values parameters must optimized, positive. idparsopt ids parameters must optimized. ids defined follows:  id = 1 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate)  id = 2 corresponds mu (extinction rate)  id = 3 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity)  id = 4 corresponds gamma (immigration rate)  id = 5 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate)  id = 6 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) optional subset species  id = 7 corresponds mu (extinction rate) optional subset species id = 8 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity) optional subset species id = 9 corresponds gamma (immigration rate) optional subset species id = 10 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate) optional subset species id = 11 corresponds p_f (fraction mainland species belongs second subset species. parsfix values parameters optimized. idparsfix ids parameters optimized, e.g. c(1,3) lambda^c K optimized. idparsmat datatype = 'multiple' : Matrix containing ids parameters, linking initparsopt parsfix. Per island system use following order:  * lac = (initial) cladogenesis rate  * mu = extinction rate  * K = maximum number species possible clade  * gam = (initial) immigration rate  * laa = (initial) anagenesis rate  Example: idparsmat = rbind(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), c(1, 2, 3, 6, 7)) different rates immigration anagenesis two islands. res Sets maximum number species probability must computed, must larger size largest clade. ddmodel Sets model diversity-dependence:  ddmodel = 0 : diversity dependence  ddmodel = 1 : linear dependence speciation rate  ddmodel = 11: linear dependence speciation rate immigration rate  ddmodel = 2 : exponential dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential dependence speciation rate immigration rate cond cond = 0 : conditioning island age  cond = 1 : conditioning island age non-extinction island biota . cond > 1 : conditioning island age least cond colonizations island. last option yet available IW model island_ontogeny DAISIE_sim_time_dep(), DAISIE_ML_CS plotting string describing type island ontogeny. Can "const", "beta" beta function describing area time.  functions numeric describing type island ontogeny. Can 0 constant, 1 beta function describing area time. ML functions island_ontogeny = NA assumes constant ontogeny. Time dependent estimation yet available development still ongoing. return error called case. tol Sets tolerances optimization. Consists :  reltolx = relative tolerance parameter values optimization  reltolf = relative tolerance function value optimization  abstolx = absolute tolerance parameter values optimization. maxiter Sets maximum number iterations optimization. methode Method ODE-solver. Supported Boost ODEINT solvers (steppers) : "odeint::runge_kutta_cash_karp54" "odeint::runge_kutta_fehlberg78" "odeint::runge_kutta_dopri5" "odeint::bulirsch_stoer" without odeint::-prefix, ode method assumed. default method overall "lsodes" DAISIE_ML_CS() "ode45" ode() DAISIE_ML_IW(). optimmethod Method used likelihood optimization. Default `subplex` (see `subplex()` full details). Alternative "simplex" method previous versions. verbose numeric vector length 1, simulations `DAISIEdataprep()` can `1` `0`, `1` gives intermediate output printed. ML functions numeric determining intermediate output printed. default: `0` print, `1` prints initial likelihood settings selected (parameters optimised, fixed shifted), `2` prints `1 also intermediate output parameters loglikelihood, `3` `2` prints intermediate progress likelihood computation. tolint Vector two elements containing absolute relative tolerance integration. jitter Numeric optimizer(). Jitters parameters optimized specified amount small, e.g. 1e-5. Jitter link{subplex}{subplex}() produces incorrect output due parameter transformation. num_cycles number cycles optimizer go . Default 1.

title: Computes MLE for multiple islands under a clade specific scenario — DAISIE_ML2
text: output dataframe containing estimated parameters maximum loglikelihood. lambda_c gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c, rate cladogenesis mu gives maximum likelihood estimate mu, extinction rate K gives maximum likelihood estimate K, carrying-capacity gamma gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma, immigration rate lambda_a gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^, rate anagenesis lambda_c2 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c2, rate cladogenesis second group species mu2 gives maximum likelihood estimate mu2, extinction rate second group species K2 gives maximum likelihood estimate K2, carrying-capacity  second group species gamma2 gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma2, immigration rate second group species lambda_a2 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^a2, rate anagenesis second group species loglik gives maximum loglikelihood df gives number estimated parameters, .e. degrees feedom conv gives message convergence optimization; conv = 0 means convergence

what: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
text: function computes maximum likelihood estimates parameters relationships parameters DAISIE model (clade-specific diversity-dependence) island area distance island mainland data lineages colonizing several islands/archipelagos. also outputs corresponding loglikelihood can used model comparisons. note sigmoidal functions used distance_dep: anagenesis cladogenesis, functional relationship k * (d/d0)^x/(1 + (d/d0)^x); colonization relationship : k - k * (d/d0)^x/(1 + (d/d0)^x). d0 parameter 11th parameter entered. 'sigmoidal_col_ana', 11th parameter d0 colonization 12th d0 anagenesis.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
code: DAISIE_MW_ML(   datalist,   initparsopt,   idparsopt,   parsfix,   idparsfix,   res = 100,   ddmodel = 11,   cond = 0,   island_ontogeny = NA,   tol = c(1e-04, 1e-05, 1e-07),   maxiter = 1000 * round((1.25)^length(idparsopt)),   methode = "lsodes",   optimmethod = "subplex",   CS_version = 1,   verbose = 0,   tolint = c(1e-16, 1e-10),   distance_type = "continent",   distance_dep = "power",   parallel = "local",   cpus = 3,   num_cycles = 1 )

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
text: datalist Data object containing information colonisation branching times species several islands archipelagos, well area, isolation age islands/archipelagos. See data(archipelagos41) example. initparsopt initial values parameters must optimized; positive idparsopt ids parameters must optimized. ids defined follows (see Valente et al 2020 Supplementary Tables 1 2 better explanation models parameters):  id = 1 corresponds lambda^c0 (cladogenesis rate unit area)  id = 2 corresponds y (exponent area cladogenesis rate)  id = 3 corresponds mu0 (extinction rate unit area)  id = 4 corresponds x (exponent 1/area extinction rate)  id = 5 corresponds K0 (clade-level carrying capacity unit area)  id = 6 corresponds z (exponent area clade-level carrying capacity)  id = 7 corresponds gamma0 (immigration rate unit distance)  id = 8 corresponds alpha (exponent 1/distance immigration rate)  id = 9 corresponds lambda^a0 (anagenesis rate unit distance)  id = 10 corresponds beta (exponent 1/distance anagenesis rate)  id = 11 corresponds d0 models M15 M19, models distance_dep = 'sigmoidal_col', 'sigmoidal_ana' 'sigmoidal_clado'; d0 colonisation (specifying distance_dep = 'sigmoidal_col_ana' id = 12 corresponds d0 anagenesis specifying distance_dep = 'sigmoidal_col_ana' parsfix values parameters optimized idparsfix ids parameters optimized, e.g. c(1,3) lambda^c K optimized. res Sets maximum number species probability must computed, must larger size largest clade ddmodel Sets model diversity-dependence:  ddmodel = 0 : diversity dependence  ddmodel = 1 : linear dependence speciation rate  ddmodel = 11: linear dependence speciation rate immigration rate  ddmodel = 2 : exponential dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential dependence speciation rate immigration rate cond cond = 0 : conditioning island age  cond = 1 : conditioning island age non-extinction island biota island_ontogeny type island ontonogeny. NA, constant ontogeny assumed tol Sets tolerances optimization. Consists :  reltolx = relative tolerance parameter values optimization  reltolf = relative tolerance function value optimization  abstolx = absolute tolerance parameter values optimization maxiter Sets maximum number iterations optimization methode Method ODE-solver. See package deSolve details. Default "lsodes" optimmethod Method used likelihood optimization. Default "subplex" (see subplex package). Alternative 'simplex' method previous versions. CS_version numeric list. Default 1 standard DAISIE model, relaxed-rate model list following elements: model: CS model run, options 1 single rate   DAISIE model, 2 multi-rate DAISIE, 0 IW test   model. relaxed_par: parameter relax (integrate ). Options "cladogenesis", "extinction", "carrying_capacity", "immigration", "anagenesis". verbose sets whether parameters likelihood printed (1) (0) tolint Vector two elements containing absolute relative tolerance integration distance_type Use 'continent' distance continent used, use 'nearest_big' distance nearest big landmass used, use 'biologically_realistic' distance take account biologically realism, e.g. average previous two thought contribute. distance_dep Sets type distance dependence used. Default power law, denoted 'power' (models M1-14 Valente et al 2020). Alternatives additive interactive contributions distance area rate cladogenesis ("area_additive_clado"; "area_interactive_clado", "area_interactive_clado1" "area_interactive_clado2"). alternatives  exponential relationship denoted 'exp'; sigmoids, either 'sigmoidal_col' sigmoid colonization, 'sigmoidal_ana' sigmoidal anagenesis, 'sigmoidal_clado' sigmoidal cladogenesis, 'sigmoidal_col_ana' sigmoids colonization anagenesis.  key different options distance_dep specified run models Valente et al 2020 (Supplementary Data Table 1 2) given :  * M1 M14 - 'power'  * M15 -'area_additive_clado'  * M16 M19 -'area_interactive_clado'  * M17 -'area_interactive_clado1'  * M18 - 'area_interactive_clado2'  * M20 M24 - sigmoidal_col'  * M21, M25 M28 - sigmoidal_ana'  * M22 M26 - 'sigmoidal_clado' * M23 M27 - 'sigmoidal_col_ana' parallel Sets whether parallel computation used. Use '' parallel computing used, 'cluster' parallel computing unix/linux cluster, 'local' parallel computation local machine. cpus Number cpus used parallel computing. Default 3. effect parallel = ''. num_cycles number cycles optimizer go . Default 1.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
text: output dataframe containing estimated parameters maximum loglikelihood. lambda_c0 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c, rate cladogenesis unit area y gives maximum likelihood estimate y, exponent area rate cladogenesis mu0 gives maximum likelihood estimate mu0, extinction rate x gives maximum likelihood estimate x, exponent 1/area extinction rate K0 gives maximum likelihood estimate K0, carrying-capacity unit area z gives maximum likelihood estimate z, exponent area carrying capacity gamma0 gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma0, immigration rate unit distance y gives maximum likelihood estimate alpha, exponent 1/distance rate colonization lambda_a0 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^a0, rate anagenesis unit distance beta gives maximum likelihood estimate beta, exponent 1/distance rate anagenesis loglik gives maximum loglikelihood df gives number estimated parameters, .e. degrees feedom conv gives message convergence optimization; conv = 0 means convergence

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
text: Valente L, Phillimore AB, Melo M, Warren BH, Clegg SM, Havenstein K,  Tiedemann R, Illera JC, Thébaud C, Aschenbach T, Etienne RS. simple dynamic model  explains island bird diversity worldwide (2020) Nature, 579, 92-96

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
text: Rampal S. Etienne & Luis Valente

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence and explicit dependencies on island area and isolation as hypothesized by MacArthur & Wilson — DAISIE_MW_ML
code: cat(" ### Fit the M19 model as in Valente et al 2020, using the ML parameters as starting values (see Supplementary Tables 1 and 2).  utils::data(archipelagos41)  DAISIE_MW_ML( datalist= archipelagos41, initparsopt = c(0.040073803,  1.945656546,  0.150429656, 67.25643672,  0.293635061,  0.059096872,  0.382688527, 0.026510781), idparsopt = c(1,3,4,7,8,9,10,11), parsfix = c(0,Inf,0) , idparsfix = c(2,5,6), res = 100, ddmodel = 0, methode = 'lsodes', cpus = 4, parallel = 'local', optimmethod = 'subplex', tol = c(1E-4, 1E-5, 1E-7), distance_type = 'continent', distance_dep = 'area_interactive_clado' ) ") #>  #> ### Fit the M19 model as in Valente et al 2020, using the ML #> parameters as starting values (see Supplementary Tables 1 and 2). #>  #> utils::data(archipelagos41) #>  #> DAISIE_MW_ML( #> datalist= archipelagos41, #> initparsopt = #> c(0.040073803,	1.945656546,	0.150429656, #> 67.25643672,	0.293635061,	0.059096872,	0.382688527, #> 0.026510781), #> idparsopt = c(1,3,4,7,8,9,10,11), #> parsfix = c(0,Inf,0) , #> idparsfix = c(2,5,6), #> res = 100, #> ddmodel = 0, #> methode = 'lsodes', #> cpus = 4, #> parallel = 'local', #> optimmethod = 'subplex', #> tol = c(1E-4, 1E-5, 1E-7), #> distance_type = 'continent', #> distance_dep = 'area_interactive_clado' #> )

title: Convert intermediate output to final simulation output — DAISIE_ONEcolonist
text: time Numeric defining length simulation time units. example, island known 4 million years old, setting time = 4 simulate entire life span island; setting time = 2 stop simulation mid-life island. island_spec Matrix current state simulation containing number species. stt_table Matrix number species time step.

title: Convert intermediate output to final simulation output — DAISIE_ONEcolonist
text: list elements: [1]: stt_table, stt_table put . [2]: branching_times, sorted numeric vector, required     ML estimation functions. first element always refers     island age. Subsequent elements refer colonisation, speciation     recolonisation times. recent recolonisation time,     always omitted approximate simulation results mathematical     formulation likelihood functions used MLE. [3]: stac, status colonist. function can     returned either 2, 4 3. stac 2, one     independent colonisation present island extant species     endemic. stac 4, singleton endemic present     present. stac 3, recolonisation occurred, one     colonising lineage. [4]: missing_species, numeric value number     missing species, , species sampled phylogeny     present island. code runs simulation models,     missing_species always set 0. [5]:   all_colonisations, recolonising lineages . comprised     $event_times $species_type: $event_times ordered numeric vectors containing       events extant recolonising lineage. includes       colonisation branching times. vector pertains one       colonising lineage. $species_type string. Can "", "C"       "" depending whether extant clade anagenetic,       cladogenetic immigrant origin, respectively.

Including 11th parameter (p_f) either idparsopt idparsfix (therefore initparsopt parsfix) optional. parameter specified, information data used, otherwise information data overruled.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_SR_ML
code: DAISIE_SR_ML_CS(   datalist,   initparsopt,   idparsopt,   parsfix,   idparsfix,   idparsnoshift = 6:10,   res = 100,   ddmodel = 0,   cond = 0,   island_ontogeny = NA,   tol = c(1e-04, 1e-05, 1e-07),   maxiter = 1000 * round((1.25)^length(idparsopt)),   methode = "lsodes",   optimmethod = "subplex",   CS_version = 1,   verbose = 0,   tolint = c(1e-16, 1e-10),   jitter = 0,   num_cycles = 1 )

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_SR_ML
text: datalist Data object containing information colonisation branching times. object can generated using DAISIE_dataprep function, converts user-specified data table data object, object can course also entered directly. R list object following elements. first element list two three components: $island_age - island age  , depending whether distinction types made, :$not_present - number mainland lineages present island  remaining elements list contains information single colonist lineage island 5 components:$colonist_name - name species clade colonized island $branching_times - island age stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge Endemic anagenetic species. cladogenetic species island age branching times radiation including stem age radiation.$stac - status colonist  * Non_endemic_MaxAge: 1  * Endemic: 2  * Endemic&Non_Endemic: 3  * Non_endemic: 4  * Endemic_MaxAge: 5 $missing_species - number island species sampled particular clade (applicable endemic clades) initparsopt initial values parameters must optimized idparsopt ids parameters must optimized. ids defined follows:  id = 1 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate)  id = 2 corresponds mu (extinction rate)  id = 3 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity)  id = 4 corresponds gamma (immigration rate)  id = 5 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate)  id = 6 corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) shift  id = 7 corresponds mu (extinction rate) shift id = 8 corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity) shift id = 9 corresponds gamma (immigration rate) shift id = 10 corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate) shift id = 11 corresponds time shift parsfix values parameters optimized idparsfix ids parameters optimized, e.g. c(1,3) lambda^c K optimized. idparsnoshift ids parameters different shift. res Sets maximum number species probability must computed, must larger size largest clade ddmodel Sets model diversity-dependence:  ddmodel = 0 : diversity dependence  ddmodel = 1 : linear dependence speciation rate  ddmodel = 11: linear dependence speciation rate immigration rate  ddmodel = 2 : exponential dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential dependence speciation rate immigration rate. cond cond = 0 : conditioning island age  cond = 1 : conditioning island age non-extinction island biota island_ontogeny type island ontonogeny. NA, constant ontogeny assumed. tol Sets tolerances optimization. Consists :  reltolx = relative tolerance parameter values optimization  reltolf = relative tolerance function value optimization  abstolx = absolute tolerance parameter values optimization. maxiter Sets maximum number iterations optimization. methode Method ODE-solver. See package deSolve details. Default "lsodes" optimmethod Method used likelihood optimization. Default "subplex" (see subplex package). Alternative 'simplex' method previous versions. CS_version numeric list. Default 1 standard DAISIE model, relaxed-rate model list following elements: model: CS model run, options 1 single rate   DAISIE model, 2 multi-rate DAISIE, 0 IW test   model. relaxed_par: parameter relax (integrate ). Options "cladogenesis", "extinction", "carrying_capacity", "immigration", "anagenesis". verbose sets whether parameters likelihood printed (1) (0). tolint Vector two elements containing absolute relative tolerance integration. jitter Numeric optimizer(). Jitters parameters optimized specified amount small, e.g. 1e-5. Jitter link[subplex]{subplex}() produces incorrect output due parameter transformation. num_cycles number cycles optimizer go . Default 1.

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_SR_ML
text: output dataframe containing estimated parameters maximum loglikelihood. lambda_c gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c, rate cladogenesis mu gives maximum likelihood estimate mu, extinction rate K gives maximum likelihood estimate K, carrying-capacity gamma gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma, immigration rate lambda_a gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^, rate anagenesis lambda_c2 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^c2, rate cladogenesis optional second group species mu2 gives maximum likelihood estimate mu2, extinction rate optional second group species K2 gives maximum likelihood estimate K2, carrying-capacity optional second group species gamma2 gives maximum likelihood estimate gamma2, immigration rate optional second group species lambda_a2 gives maximum likelihood estimate lambda^a2, rate anagenesis optional second group species loglik gives maximum loglikelihood df gives number estimated parameters, .e. degrees feedom conv gives message convergence optimization; conv = 0 means convergence

title: Maximization of the loglikelihood under the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence — DAISIE_SR_ML
code: # \donttest{ ## In all following DAISIE_ML calls very high tolerances and low system size ## are used  for fast computation for this example. Use default or better ## tol, tolint an res values in actual analyses. ################## ### When all species have the same rates, and we want to optimize all 5 ### parameters, we use: utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist,    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01),    ddmodel = 11,    idparsopt = 1:5,    parsfix = NULL,    idparsfix = NULL,    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50 ) #>   lambda_c       mu  K gamma lambda_a    loglik df conv #> 1  2.15493 2.153129 20 0.009     1.01 -81.28596  5    0  ### When all species have the same rates, and we want to optimize all parameters # except K (which we set equal to Inf), we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist,    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,0.009,1.01),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5),    parsfix = Inf,    idparsfix = 3,    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50    ) #>   lambda_c       mu   K gamma lambda_a    loglik df conv #> 1 3.180506 3.172027 Inf 0.009     1.01 -73.14958  4    0  ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different # rate of cladogenesis, and we want to optimize all parameters except K (which we # set equal to Inf), fixing the proportion of finch-type species at 0.163, we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types,    initparsopt = c(0.38,0.55,0.004,1.1,2.28),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,6),    parsfix = c(Inf,Inf,0.163),    idparsfix = c(3,8,11),    idparsnoshift = c(7,9,10),    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50    ) #>    lambda_c        mu   K       gamma lambda_a lambda_c2       mu2  K2 #> 1 0.3840537 0.6146573 Inf 0.003956464 1.193755  3.079965 0.6146573 Inf #>        gamma2 lambda_a2 prop_type2    loglik df conv #> 1 0.003956464  1.193755      0.163 -69.57021  5    0  ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different # rate of cladogenesis, extinction and a different K, and we want to optimize all # parameters, fixing the proportion of finch-type species at 0.163, we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types,    ddmodel = 11,    initparsopt = c(0.19,0.09,0.002,0.87,20,8.9,15),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,6,7,8),    parsfix = c(Inf,0.163),    idparsfix = c(3,11),    idparsnoshift = c(9,10),    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50    ) #>    lambda_c        mu   K       gamma lambda_a lambda_c2     mu2       K2 #> 1 0.2085388 0.1294331 Inf 0.002834096 1.115621  17.09695 6.32994 18.72603 #>        gamma2 lambda_a2 prop_type2    loglik df conv #> 1 0.002834096  1.115621      0.163 -64.80759  7    0   ### When all species have the same rates except that the finches have a different # rate of extinction, and we want to optimize all parameters except K (which we # set equal to Inf), and we also# want to estimate the fraction of finch species # in the mainland pool. we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist_2types) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Galapagos_datalist_2types,    initparsopt = c(2.48,2.7,0.009,1.01,2.25,0.163),    idparsopt = c(1,2,4,5,7,11),    parsfix = c(Inf,Inf),    idparsfix = c(3,8),    idparsnoshift = c(6,9,10),    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50    ) #>   lambda_c       mu   K       gamma lambda_a lambda_c2      mu2  K2      gamma2 #> 1  2.55745 3.239773 Inf 0.009729946 1.739499   2.55745 1.599674 Inf 0.009729946 #>   lambda_a2  prop_type2    loglik df conv #> 1  1.739499 0.001157252 -71.91278  6    0  ### When we have two islands with the same rates except for immigration and anagenesis rate, # and we want to optimize all parameters, we use:  utils::data(Galapagos_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = list(Galapagos_datalist,Galapagos_datalist),    datatype = 'multiple',    initparsopt = c(2.5,2.7,20,0.009,1.01,0.009,1.01),    idparsmat = rbind(1:5,c(1:3,6,7)),    idparsopt = 1:7,    parsfix = NULL,    idparsfix = NULL,    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50 ) #>   lambda_c       mu        K       gamma lambda_a    loglik df conv #> 1   2.3754 2.276205 12.28802 0.008006759 1.223171 -147.3063  7    0 #> 2   2.3754 2.276205 12.28802 0.006590183 1.054042 -147.3063  7    0  ### When we consider the four Macaronesia archipelagoes and set all parameters the same # except for rates of cladogenesis, extinction and immigration for Canary Islands, # rate of cladogenesis is fixed to 0 for the other archipelagoes, # diversity-dependence is assumed to be absent # and we want to optimize all parameters, we use:  utils::data(Macaronesia_datalist) DAISIE_ML(    datalist = Macaronesia_datalist,    datatype = 'multiple',    initparsopt = c(1.053151832,0.052148979,0.512939011,0.133766934,0.152763179),    idparsmat = rbind(1:5,c(6,2,3,7,5),1:5,1:5),    idparsopt = c(2,4,5,6,7),    parsfix = c(0,Inf),    idparsfix = c(1,3),    tol = c(0.1, 0.02, 0.01),    tolint = c(1e-4, 1e-2),    res = 50 ) #>     lambda_c       mu   K      gamma lambda_a    loglik df conv #> 1 0.00000000 1.053152 Inf 0.05214898 0.512939 -447.8626  5    0 #> 2 0.09497184 1.053152 Inf 0.15276318 0.512939 -447.8626  5    0 #> 3 0.00000000 1.053152 Inf 0.05214898 0.512939 -447.8626  5    0 #> 4 0.00000000 1.053152 Inf 0.05214898 0.512939 -447.8626  5    0  # }

title: Computes the loglikelihood of the DAISIE model with clade-specific diversity-dependence given data and a set of model parameters that may shift at some time — DAISIE_SR_loglik_CS
text: pars1 Contains model parameters: pars1[1] corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) pars1[2] corresponds mu (extinction rate) pars1[3] corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity) pars1[4] corresponds gamma (immigration rate) pars1[5] corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate) pars1[6] corresponds lambda^c (cladogenesis rate) shift pars1[7] corresponds mu (extinction rate) shift pars1[8] corresponds K (clade-level carrying capacity) shift pars1[9] corresponds gamma (immigration rate) shift pars1[10] corresponds lambda^(anagenesis rate) shift pars1[11] corresponds time shift pars2 Contains model settings pars2[1] corresponds lx = length ODE variable x pars2[2] corresponds ddmodel = diversity-dependent model, model diversity-dependence, can one ddmodel = 0 : diversity dependence  ddmodel = 1 : linear dependence speciation rate  ddmodel = 11: linear dependence speciation rate immigration rate  ddmodel = 2 : exponential dependence speciation rate ddmodel = 21: exponential dependence speciation rate immigration ratepars2[3] corresponds cond = setting conditioning cond = 0 : conditioning island age  cond = 1 : conditioning island age non-extinction island biota  cond > 1 : conditioning island age least cond colonizations island pars2[4] sets whether parameters likelihood printed (1) (0) datalist Data object containing information colonisation branching times. object can generated using DAISIE_dataprep function, converts user-specified data table data object, object can course also entered directly. R list object following elements. first element list two three components: $island_age - island age  , depending whether distinction types made, :$not_present - number mainland lineages present island  remaining elements list contains information single colonist lineage island 5 components:$colonist_name - name species clade colonized island $branching_times - island age stem age population/species case Non-endemic, Non-endemic_MaxAge Endemic anagenetic species. cladogenetic species island age branching times radiation including stem age radiation.$stac - status colonist  - Non_endemic_MaxAge: 1  * Endemic: 2  - Endemic&Non_Endemic: 3  - Non_endemic: 4  - Endemic_MaxAge: 5 $missing_species - number island species sampled particular clade (applicable endemic clades) methode Method ODE-solver. See package deSolve details. Default "lsodes" CS_version numeric list. Default 1 standard DAISIE model, relaxed-rate model list following elements: model: CS model run, options 1 single rate   DAISIE model, 2 multi-rate DAISIE, 0 IW test   model. relaxed_par: parameter relax (integrate ). Options "cladogenesis", "extinction", "carrying_capacity", "immigration", "anagenesis". abstolint Absolute tolerance integration reltolint Relative tolerance integration

code: ### Compute the probability distribution at t = 4 and t = 8, for a mainland pool # size of 250 potential colonists and a vector of 5 parameters (cladogenesis, extinction, # clade-level carrying capacity, immigration, anagenesis) starting from an empty # island; store in list format  pb <- DAISIE_probdist(    pars1 = c(0.3,0.35,Inf,0.75,0.012),    pars2 = c(100,250),    tvec = c(4,8),    initEI = c(0,0),    initprobs = NULL    ) prob_dists <- DAISIE_convertprobdist(pb)
